thought:
I have a degree in Mechanical Engineering from Columbia University.

(That doesn't mean so much anymore since it was so long ago - I just needed to slide that fact in there somewhere.)

I've worked in print, [a bit of] video and "the interwebs" since 1990.

READ: I remember answering machines, beepers, BBS (Bulletin Board Services) and when the internet was called Mosaic.
I've worked both the service side and client side of marketing / advertising / publishing.

I *NEVER* say, "no" to getting a job done well, efficiently and, most of all, effectively.

I am in constant pursuit of excellence.

I've done work across several industries including fashion, beauty, entertainment, health, pharmaceutical and tech.

It's a part of my "Never Say No" approach to a strong work ethic.

I've jumped from a cliff into the Colorado River despite a stultifying fear of heights.

It changed my outlook on life and gave me a new mantra to live by:
*Never* listen to your friends... especially when they can't stop giggling.

I enjoy skiing, snowboarding, archery and skeet shooting.

I am mediocre at all of these things.

I rowed in college.

I was significantly smaller than most rowers, but I had a really good stroke.

I don't look like it, but I play a mean game of pool.

It's fun to sneak up on the guy who's a bit arrogant about his game... then make best friends with him.

I have an off-color sense of humor ranging from that of a 12 year old boy to an 80 year old dowager.

It's a gift.

I like to toy with microprocessing / microcomputing (arduino, rapsberry pi, etc.)

... and I have a slight obsession with LEDs.

I *RARELY* say, "no" when it comes to work and play.

I am in constant pursuit of combining the two.
My *favorite* niece, Mori-chan (who is looking over my shoulder right now), made me add this thought bubble.

The toilet paper roll should *always* feed from the top, and here is why:

if you try to *snap* off the amount you want, it is likely to over-roll.

If the toilet paper feeds from the bottom, there is a 2*PI*r increase in chance that dangling the end of the roll will land on the floor.

ew.
